tossups.question: In an early paper, this scientist used 6 NAND operations and 3 variables to create an equivalent statement to the axioms of Boolean algebra. This scientist presented the original conjecture that Rule 110 was a Turing complete system. A k digit number and S number of states are the inputs to this scientist’s namesake “code” for naming one-dimensional (*) cellular automata. This scientist’s namesake language was developed for use with Raspberry Pi devices, which would also come equipped with his namesake computational software designed to improve upon CAS technology. For 10 points, name this British-American computer scientist who developed Mathematica and lends his name to an online computational engine, “Alpha”.
tossups.answer: Stephen Wolfram [Accept Wolfram Alpha, Wolfram Mathematica, or Wolfram Language]
tossups.answer_formatted: Stephen Wolfram [Accept Wolfram Alpha, Wolfram Mathematica, or Wolfram Language]

tossups.question: A book by William Urricchio and Susanne Kinnebrock titled for the “Cultures” of these entities analyzes how they have changed in the aftermath of 9/11. In a 1946 paper, two sociologists argued that one type of these entities caused "narcotizing dysfunction," where the populace substitutes knowledge for action. One of those sociologists, Paul Lazarsfeld, argued that (*) information passing through one of these entities undergoes a two-step flow of communication. A book titled Understanding these entities argued for dividing them into "hot" and "cool" varieties based on their ease of use and level of engagement. For 10 points, name these entities used for communication studied by Marshall McLuhan, whose "social" varities include platforms like Facebook and Twitter.
tossups.answer: media [or mediums; accept specific kinds of media such as mass media or social media]
tossups.answer_formatted: media [or mediums; accept specific kinds of media such as mass media or social media]
acceptable: specific kinds of media such as mass media

tossups.question: The line “delightful sickness entered unto mine” describes the clearing of this person’s eye infection. An author discusses this person and literary fame in a dialogue with St. Augustine called Secretum Meum. In a poem dedicated to this person, the author claims “I hope to find pity, and forgiveness / for all the modes in which I talk and weep.” A poetry collection was divided into sections (*) “before” and “after” this person’s death from the bubonic plague. That collection, which opens “You who hear the sound, in scattered rhymes,” was dedicated to this woman, who was first spotted by an author at a church service on Good Friday in 1327. That author wrote about his love for this woman in a collection of 366 sonnets titled Il Canzoniere. For 10 points, name this love interest of Petrarch.
tossups.answer: Laura [or Laura de Noves]
tossups.answer_formatted: Laura [or Laura de Noves]

tossups.question: American missionary Ellen Maria Stone was kidnapped by an organization based in this peninsula in a major early 20th century hostage crisis. A prime minister in this peninsula had his hand and head cut off and stuffed into a box of biscuits after signing the Treaty of Nis. The Salonika trial purged a revolutionary organization based in this peninsula after its most famous action at the (*) Latin Bridge. Alexander Stamboliyski was assassinated by IMRO, which advocated for a state in this peninsula. Two wars named for this peninsula preceded World War I. Apis led an organization in this peninsula that killed Duchess Sophie in 1914. For 10 points, name this peninsula, home to the Black Hand’s Serbian nationalists.
tossups.answer: Balkan Peninsula [or Balkans]
tossups.answer_formatted: Balkan Peninsula [or Balkans]

tossups.question: “Balancing” this property is necessary during echocardiography since systole produces negative and positive values for its circumferential and transmural components, respectively. Silicon can be induced to have this property by doping a p-channel MOSFET with germanium to increase hole mobility. Calculations involving this property traditionally convert from its Eulerian form to its Lagrangian form prior to integrating the velocity gradient. (*) “Necking” is a phenomenon that occurs when a measure of this property is localized. This property is traditionally plotted on the x-axis of a curve in which fractures are denoted by an “X” and a quantity equal to force over area is on the y-axis. For 10 points, name this quantity plotted against stress on that curve.
tossups.answer: strain [accept strain rate; strained silicon; strain tensor or strain-rate tensor or rate-of-strain tensor; prompt on velocity gradient before mention; do not accept or prompt on any answers involving stress]
tossups.answer_formatted: strain [accept strain rate; strained silicon; strain tensor or strain-rate tensor or rate-of-strain tensor; prompt on velocity gradient before mention; do not accept or prompt on "any answers involving stress"]

tossups.question: Near the end of this novel, one character commits suicide with a "wonderful lamp," which is actually a pistol. That man in this novel reveals intimate details about his lover to a man who uses the details to make threatening phone calls. The black activist Dr. Simba dies in police custody after being accused of committing the "Granny Ripper murders" in this novel. A girl in this novel dresses in, and eats, (*) butterflies. One man in this novel dates a mountain climber named Allie Cone. One storyline in this novel ends as a group of pilgrims drown in the Arabian Sea, while another follows Muhammad as he receives the title blasphemous instruction. For 10 points, name this novel about Saladin Chamcha and Gibreel Farishta, written by Salman Rushdie.
tossups.answer: The Satanic Verses
tossups.answer_formatted: The Satanic Verses

tossups.question: A church made of orange crates was built in a racially-integrated one of these places led by pastor Gus Smith. One of these places in Chicago elected disabled rail worker Mike Donovan as mayor. Men in these places took pride in saying “I am not on relief” according to a memoir by former lumberjack Jesse Jackson. Men who inhabited these places were (*) “Cheered in ‘17, Jeered in ‘32” and resided in Anacostia Flats. The Bonus Army lived in one of these places, which were named after a person who had promised “a chicken in every pot and a car in every garage”. These specific places popped up after Black Tuesday in 1929. For 10 points each, name these shantytowns, named after a president who failed to provide relief during the Great Depression.
tossups.answer: Hoovervilles [prompt on shantytowns, slums, tent cities/encampment(s), homeless camp(s), or other equivalents; say “I need a specific name”]
tossups.answer_formatted: Hoovervilles [prompt on shantytowns, slums, tent cities/encampment(s), homeless camp(s), or other equivalents; say “I need a specific name”]
promptable: shantytowns, slums, tent cities/encampment(s), homeless camp(s),

tossups.question: This condition can be reproduced in mice with systemic pilocarpine injections. This condition presents with an abnormal persistence of Cajal-Retzius cells and a dispersion of granule cells controlled by local reelin deficiencies. Ammon’s horn sclerosis is the most common tissue damage associated with this condition. An “initial precipitating injury” and a “latency period” typically precede the symptoms of this condition. This condition was treated by (*) removing the hippocampus in the patient “H.M.”. Between 10% and 20% of deaths from this condition are referred to as “sudden and unexpected”. This condition’s primary symptom may occur in a “tonic-clonic” type. For 10 points, name this condition characterized by unprovoked seizures.
tossups.answer: epilepsy [accept temporal lobe epilepsy or parietal lobe epilepsy; prompt on answers mentioning seizures with “As a result of what other condition?”]
tossups.answer_formatted: epilepsy [accept temporal lobe epilepsy or parietal lobe epilepsy; prompt on answers mentioning seizures with “As a result of what other condition?]
promptable: answers mentioning seizures with “As a result of what other condition?

tossups.question: This book argued that an earlier thinker's 12 categories of human experience could be reduced to just causality. This book uses the "double-knowledge" of its author's body to reject Cartesean dualism. This book created a hierarchy of fine arts, with poetry and music at the top. This book advocates for aesthetic contemplation as a way to reduce human (*) suffering and states that humans live in the "worst of all possible worlds." This book claims that the ding an sich, or the "thing-in-itself" pervades the universe in a critique of Kant which drew on the Upanishads. For 10 points, name this book which claims that the title two concepts comprise human experience, a work by Arthur Schopenhaur.
tossups.answer: The World as Will and Representation [or Die Welt als Wille und Vorstellung; or The World as Will and Idea; or The World as Will and Presentation]
tossups.answer_formatted: The World as Will and Representation [or Die Welt als Wille und Vorstellung; or The World as Will or Idea; or The World as Will or Presentation]
acceptable: The World as Will and Representation
Die Welt als Wille und Vorstellung

tossups.question: After this figure was cursed by the Kumaras, he and his brother were born as the second reincarnation of the doorkeepers of Vishnu. This figure was given the Chandrahas sword by his patron god after attempting to lift that god's residence. After this figure beheaded himself to complete his penance, Shiva gave him his most notable physical feature. After committing his most famous crime, this figure slew (*) Jatayu while fleeing on his vimana, or flying chariot. As retaliation for Lakshaman cutting off Surphanaka's ears and nose, this figure ordered Maricha to transform into a golden deer and distract his main enemy. While disguised as a sage, this figure kidnapped Sita. For 10 points, name this ten-headed king of Lanka from the Ramayana.
tossups.answer: Ravana [or Ravan; or Dashanan]
tossups.answer_formatted: Ravana [or Ravan; or Dashanan]

tossups.question: In one novel, a character with this profession is gunned down in a graveyard while thinking of his daughter Sana. That character with this profession falls in love with Nur and seeks revenge on his ex-wife and his old mentor Rauf after his release from prison. In one story, the body of a character killed by members of this profession is sewed back together by a tailor. Said Marwan is the protagonist of a (*) Naguib Mahfouz novel titled for a member of this profession and the Dogs. In one story, some of these people hiding in jars have hot oil poured on them by Morgiana. Members of this profession pursue a woodcutter after he discovers a cave full of riches that opens with the password “Open sesame.” For 10 points, name this profession, forty members of whom pursue Ali Baba in the Arabian Nights.
tossups.answer: thieves [accept robbers or other synonyms; or thief; or thievery; accept The Thief and the Dogs; accept “Ali Baba and the Forty Thieves”]
tossups.answer_formatted: thieves [accept robbers or other synonyms; or thief; or thievery; accept The Thief or the Dogs; accept Ali Baba or the Forty Thieves]

tossups.question: An independence activist in this country nicknamed the “Golden Swallow of Democracy” was murdered in 1998 and a vinegar bottle and soy sauce packet were inexplicably taken from his home by the assailants. After the mysterious death of Marshal Demid in this country, Buddhists were killed in mass purges. Bogd (*) Khan was restored to this country’s throne by the “Mad Baron” Roman von Ungern-Sternberg. Stalinist control of this country led to its capital being renamed “Red Square”. Yumjaagin Tsedenbal was forced to censor teachings about a historical icon in this country who later received a large statue in Sukhbataar Square. For 10 points, name this country, where veneration of Genghis Khan was suppressed during Soviet control.
tossups.answer: Mongolian People’s Republic
tossups.answer_formatted: Mongolian People’s Republic

tossups.question: One artist with this surname was commissioned by the Special Olympics to depict North Carolina landmarks, such as the Duke Chapel, in the style of her characteristically warm seascapes. Another contemporary artist with this surname is best-known for depictions of dream-like, Parisian street scenes in his primitive, naif style. An earlier artist with this surname created a smoky depiction of the River Styx being crossed by figures carrying the title poet in his first major work. Golden (*) elephant heads adorn the opulent bed of an Assyrian king in another work by that artist of the Barque of Dante, who had this surname. For 10 points, give this surname of the artist of The Death of Sardanapalus and Liberty Leading the People, who’s first name was Eugene.
tossups.answer: Delacroix [Fabienne Delacroix or Michel Delacroix or Eugene Delacroix]
tossups.answer_formatted: Delacroix [Fabienne Delacroix or Michel Delacroix or Eugene Delacroix]

tossups.question: Robert Rounseville and Moira Shearer star in a 1951 film adaptation of an opera by this composer, the last major film of Powell and Pressburger. In one work by this composer, “Duo de la mouche” is sung by Jupiter, who is disguised as a fly. The frame story of an opera by this composer takes place in Luther’s Tavern. In that opera by this composer, the aria (*) “Belle nuit, ô nuit d'amour,” a venetian barcarolle, is sung by Giulietta and Nicklausse. This man is most famous for composing an “Infernal Galop” that accompanied a dance popular in nightclubs where women stand in a line and perform high kicks. For 10 points, name this French composer of The Tales of Hoffmann whose operetta Orpheus in the Underworld contains a “can-can.”
tossups.answer: Jacques Offenbach
tossups.answer_formatted: Jacques Offenbach

tossups.question: Multiple atoms of this element replace methyl hydrogens in a class of methylation reaction exemplified by the McLoughlin-Thrower reaction and commonly used in the field of drug development. Atoms of this element are substituted for a larger element from the same group in the Swarts reaction. Phenyl groups are substituted with atoms of this element in the drugs Paxil and Prozac. This is the negatively charged atom in a quaternary ammonium salt used to remove (*) silyl ether protecting groups. Three atoms of this element are present in a derivative of acetic acid that is roughly 30,000 times as acidic due to the inductive effect. A class of compound consisting of this element, chlorine, and carbon have been banned for contributing to ozone depletion. For 10 points, name this most electronegative halogen on the Pauling scale.
tossups.answer: fluorine [or F or TFA or TBAF; accept difluoromethylation or trifluoromethylation; prompt on CFCs]
tossups.answer_formatted: fluorine [or F or TFA or TBAF; accept difluoromethylation or trifluoromethylation; prompt on CFCs]

tossups.question: A round, basalt relief from this modern-day country consists of 15 repeated friezes of its namesake king grasping a conquered warrior by the hair. This is the largest modern-day nation from which an indigenous sculptural motif featuring reclining figures resting on their elbows with heads at 90-degree angles originates. A mosaic of red oyster shells, conch shells, and turquoise adorns a two-headed wooden sculpture created by native artisans from this country. In addition to the Double (*) Serpent, this country is home to an artifact possessing glyphs that radiate from a central disk in a stone sculpture, which is divided into areas such as "4 Wind" and "4 Jaguar" and has been dubbed the "Sun Stone." For 10 points, name this country whose art has been heavily influenced by its Aztec and Mayan traditions.
tossups.answer: Mexico [or Estados Unidos Mexicanos or United Mexican States] Stone of Tizoc, the 2nd clue refers to Chacmool sculptures]
tossups.answer_formatted: Mexico Stone of Tizoc, the 2nd clue refers to Chacmool sculptures] [or Estados Unidos Mexicanos or United Mexican States]
acceptable: Mexico Stone of Tizoc, the 2nd clue refers to Chacmool sculptures]

tossups.question: A character in this play wishes for “the Cornelly place” on Jekyll Island while raising his drink while his brother “saw the bricks going into place.” A character in this play is surprised by a worker’s strike in Massachusetts in a conversation with Mr. Marshall. A servant in this play wipes his hands whenever he is (*) lying. Addie is warned of people who “eat the earth” in this play after Leo steals from a safe deposit box containing a baby shoe and a piece of a violin. The wheelchair-bound Horace returns from Baltimore in this play and refuses to give his Union Pacific bonds to his sister. Regina, Benjamin, and Oscar’s plan to build a cotton mill falls apart in this play. For 10 points, name this play about the Giddens family by Lillian Hellmann.
tossups.answer: The Little Foxes
tossups.answer_formatted: The Little Foxes

tossups.question: An early cartoon supporting this movement was made by James Gillray and depicted several animals emerging from people's bodies. In Australia, members of this movement have founded fake religions such as the Church of Conscious Living. In California, one member of this movement protested a pair of laws by throwing a menstrual cup full of (*) blood into the senate chamber. Some members of this movement raise concerns over the preservative thimerosal, which contains mercury. Despite having to retract his research, Andrew Wakefield remains an important figure in this movement. For 10 points, name this social movement, which opposes medical care that can prevent infectious diseases.
tossups.answer: anti-vaccination [or anti-vax; or anti-vaccine; accept vaccine hesitancy; accept vaccine skepticism; accept any answer indicating people not liking vaccines; prompt on answers such as alternative medicine or pseudo-medicine]
tossups.answer_formatted: anti-vaccination [or anti-vax; or anti-vaccine; accept vaccine hesitancy; accept vaccine skepticism; accept any answer indicating people not liking vaccines; prompt on answers such as alternative medicine or pseudo-medicine]

tossups.question: One of these people named Frank the Poet composed poems such as “Moreton Bay” documenting his experiences. Architect Francis Greenway was a prominent member of the “emancipist” faction of these people, which opposed the “exclusives”. It’s not Irish, but Philip Cunningham led a group of these people at the Second Battle of Vinegar Hill. Arthur Philip led the first group of these people to (*) Port Jackson aboard the HMS Sirius. The Hougoumont was the last “hulk” to hold these people, who were aboard the First Fleet. Descendants of these people fought the Black War. Botany Bay was deemed unsuitable for the settlement of these people. For 10 points, name these undesirables who settled an island after being sentenced to penal transportation.
tossups.answer: Australian convicts [accept anything indicating the first settlers of Australia or prisoners sent to Australia; prompt on prisoners or equivalents with “in what location?”]
tossups.answer_formatted: Australian convicts [accept anything indicating the first settlers of Australia or prisoners sent to Australia; prompt on prisoners or equivalents with “in what location?]
acceptable: anything indicating the first settlers of Australia

tossups.question: Confirmation in this religion takes place with the Pact of the Time Custodian, which practitioners believe was signed by all members of this religion in a past life. At the end of the reincarnation cycle, practitioners of this religion believe that believer's souls will be united with the Cosmic Mind. This religion maintains the Nabi Shu'ayb, which contains the tomb of Jethro. This religion's chief texts are the Epistles of (*) Wisdom, some of which were written by al-Hakim. This religion was originally founded as an offshoot of the Ismali movement and this religion is represented by a five pointed multi-colored star. For 10 points, name this syncretic offshoot of Islam, which is mainly based in Palestine, Lebanon, and Syria.
tossups.answer: Druze [prompt on al-Muwahhidun or The People of Monotheism]
tossups.answer_formatted: Druze [prompt on al-Muwahhidun or The People of Monotheism]

bonuses.leadin: Eugene Schieffelin attempted to introduce every bird mentioned by Shakespeare into Central Park. For 10 points each:
answers: Henry IV, Part 1 [prompt on Henry IV]
parts: Schieffelin brought the first European starlings to America, which is now home to over 200 million of them. Starlings are mentioned in this history play when Hotspur wonders if he could train one to speak Mortimer’s name.

Schieffelin was one of the first people to import house sparrows to North America. This character notes that “there is special providence in the fall of a sparrow,” a premonition of his death and his last words, “The rest is silence.”
The attempt to introduce skylarks and nightingales proved less successful; both birds are mentioned in a speech by this member of the Capulet family who falls in love with a boy from the Montagues.

bonuses.leadin: In a book titled for a pivot of history named for this field, one thinker argued that control of the heartland was necessary for global political power. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this field of study of the shape and features of the Earth's surface. This field's human subfield studies the ways that humans interact with and shape their environments.

This geopolitical theorist created the heartland theory of geopolitics, which he outlined in his book The Geographic Pivot of History. This geographer was the first European to ascend Mt. Kenya, where he allegedly massacred his eight Swahili porters.
Mackinder considered the "pivot" to stretch from the Yangtze River in China to this other river. This river rises in the Valdai Hills and has the cities of Kazan and Astrakhan along its shores.

bonuses.leadin: Symptoms of a namesake “syndrome” affecting streams in these locations include flashier hydrographs, altered channel morphologies, and reduced biotic richness. For 10 points each:
answers: urban area(s) [accept cities or suburban areas or word forms like suburbs; accept urban stream syndrome]
impervious [accept word forms, such as imperviousness]
surface runoff [accept overland flow or agricultural runoff; prompt on (stormwater) discharge]
parts: Name these general locations within which water systems are protected by “low impact development”. Streams in these areas are typically ecologically distinct due to the effects of minimal leaf breakdown and stormwater piping.

Urban stream health has an inversely proportional relationship to the number of surfaces in the area described by this adjective, such as asphalt and concrete. Those structures described by this adjective impede natural water infiltration and redirect stormwater flow.
This general term refers to the excess flow of water across a landscape. This process is a major cause of soil erosion and the deposition of harmful nutrients and chemicals into waterways.
answers_formatted: urban area [accept cities or suburban areas or word forms like suburbs; accept urban stream syndrome]
surface runoff [accept overland flow or agricultural runoff; prompt on (stormwater) discharge]

bonuses.leadin: Users of this system called chasquis sometimes used baskets on zip lines called oroya. For 10 points each:
answers: Incan road system [or Qhapaq Nañ; accept anything involving Inca and transportation of some sort]
parts: Name this system where chasquis were often targeted by bandits called pomaranra. Along this system, chasquis stopped at qollqa storehouses to pick up and drop off goods.
Incan roads all originated in this Incan capital city from which the four suyus, or cardinal directions began.
Chasquis runners carried this traditional fermented alcoholic beverage of the Inca. Women called aqlla lived in compounds their entire lives performing ceremonial tasks such as brewing this beverage.
answers_formatted: Incan road system [or Qhapaq Nañ; accept anything involving Inca or transportation of some sort]

bonuses.leadin: This psychoanalyst used the example of infants staring at their mother's faces and touching their breasts to argue that the mother-infant bond was more significant than just feeding and development. For 10 points each:
answers: Freud [accept Sigmund Freud or Anna Freud]
parts: Name this psychoanalyst, who argued for the existence of the superego from birth in The Psychoanalysis of Children.

Klein's arguments regarding aggression and child analysis caused a rift between her and a woman with this surname. That psychoanalyst was the daughter of the author of The Interpretation of Dreams, who also shares this surname.

Klein described these two concepts as an opposing kind of "life pulsation" and "death pulsation." Sigmund Freud referred to these two concepts as the driving forces of life, and they are usually translated as the life and death drives.

bonuses.leadin: A common 32-bar chord progression often used for improvisation is named for this song’s “changes.” For 10 points each:
answers: “I Got Rhythm” [prompt on rhythm changes by asking “What is the name of the song?”]
parts: Name this jazz standard originally from the musical Girl Crazy. Its singer claims “Old Man trouble, I don’t mind him,” and “Who could ask for anything more?”
“I Got Rhythm” was written by Ira and composed by George, a pair of brothers with this last name responsible for the opera Porgy and Bess.
One of the most famous songs to use rhythm changes was this 1946 bebop song written by Charlie Parker after Dizzy Gillespie left his band. Parker supposedly named this song after his heroin dealer.
answers_formatted: “I Got Rhythm” [prompt on rhythm changes by asking “What is the name of the song?]

bonuses.leadin: This technique makes use of a running buffer consisting of Tris-base, acetic acid, and EDTA called TAE. For 10 points each:
answers: gel electrophoresis [anti-prompt (“be less specific…”) on (SDS) PAGE]
mobility shift assay [or MC-EMSA or electrophoretic mobility shift assay or mobility shift electrophoresis or gel shift assay or gel retardation assay]
parts: Name this common benchtop technique typically run after PCR to visualize the results. Samples in this technique are loaded into wells in a gel matrix and stained with dyes like ethidium bromide.

When doing a Western blot, a common intermediate step is to stain your sample with Ponceau S and run it on a gel to confirm that you have protein. Ponceau staining creates bands of this color when visualized, which is also the color of the side on a standard electrophoresis box that DNA runs toward.

Electrophoresis is also used in this other assay for analyzing DNA-protein interactions by mixing labeled DNA with a protein of interest, running them on a gel, and observing the namesake result relative to a DNA-only lane.
answers_formatted: mobility shift assay [or MC-EMSA or electrophoretic mobility shift assay or mobility shift electrophoresis or gel shift assay or gel retardation assay]

bonuses.leadin: This place appears twice in the title of a poem that contains the questions “Say, who are you that mumbles in the dark?” and “Who said the free? Not me?” For 10 points each:
answers: America [or the United States of America; or USA; accept “Let America Be America Again” or “I, Too, Sing America”]
Langston Hughes [or James Mercer Langston Hughes]
parts: Name this place. The narrator of another poem shows his loyalty to this place by promising to “be at the table / When company comes.”
This author of “Let America Be America Again” and “I, Too, Sing America” was a major figure of the Harlem Renaissance. His poem “Harlem” asks “What happens to a dream deferred?”
In this Langston Hughes poem, the speaker writes “I am the only colored student in my class” after an “instructor” tells him “Go home and write / a page tonight.”
answers_formatted: America [or the United States of America; or USA; accept Let America Be America Again or I, Too, Sing America]

bonuses.leadin: During the Renaissance, a stylistic controversy arose over the relative merits of paintings created in the more spontaneous colorito style and paintings created in this style. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this style of painting that emphasized the value of preparatory studies and preliminary drawings. Stylistically, paintings in this style were representative of the Central Italian tradition. Either the Italian or English term is acceptable.

Whereas disegno paintings were emblematic of Central Italian art, the colorito style was championed by painters from this other Italian city. A colorito depiction of this city’s patron saint and its many canals can be seen in Carpaccio’s The Lion of St. Mark.

This art historian described the disegno approach of artists like Michelangelo as the “father of all the visual arts”. That description can be found in his work Lives of the Most Eminent Painters, Sculptors, and Architects.

bonuses.leadin: NOTE TO MODERATOR: For the 3rd part, if you do not wish to say “fuck”, just say “F”John Roberts’ opinion in a 2007 case declared that although this four-word phrase was “cryptic”, it could be interpreted as stating that a certain action was a “good thing”. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this specific four-word phrase that was displayed across the street from Juneau-Douglas High School during the 2002 Winter Olympics Torch Relay, prompting retaliation from Deborah Morse.

The Supreme Court ruled against Joseph Frederick, the student who held up that poster, denying the Ninth Circuit’s assertion that this previous 1969 case involving black armbands applied in Morse v. Frederick.
The plaintiffs in Tinker were protesting this conflict. This conflict was also protested by the plaintiff in Cohen v. California, who wore a shirt that said “FUCK THE DRAFT”.

bonuses.leadin: This novel opens with Colonel Aureliano Buendia facing a firing squad and remembering when his father took him to discover ice. For 10 points each:
answers: One Hundred Years of Solitude [or Cien años de soledad]
parts: Name this novel by Gabriel García Márquez about the residents of Macondo.
Otto Dietrich zur Linde, a concentration camp commandant, writes his unrepentant last testament while awaiting his execution by firing squad in this short story by Jorge Luis Borges (“BOR-hays”).
Tomas Arroyo and the corpse of the title character are shot at by a firing squad at the end of this author’s novel The Old Gringo.
answers_formatted: One Hundred Years of Solitude [or Cien años de soledad]

bonuses.leadin: Gong Cha and CoCo Fresh are franchises that primarily sell this beverage. For 10 points each:
answers: taro [or taro root; or Colocasia esculenta; or dasheen; or yautia; or eddo; or kalo]
parts: Name this trendy Taiwanese drink that typically contains chewy tapioca pearls.

A common variety of bubble tea adds this purple, starchy plant to it. This plant looks similar to a sweet potato, is a staple crop in many Caribbean and Pacific nations, and is used to make the Hawaiian dish poi.
Bubble tea can also be made using this dark tea with a malty flavor that is often used for English breakfast tea. It is named for the northeastern Indian state that contains Kaziranga National Park.
answers_formatted: taro [or taro root; or Colocasia esculenta; or dasheen; or yautia; or eddo; or kalo]

bonuses.leadin: In the paper "What the Tortoise Said to Achilles," Lewis Carol describes how the Tortoise traps Achilles in this sort of logical problem. For 10 points each:
answers: infinite regress [or reductio ad infinitum; prompt on paradoxes]
modus ponens [or modus ponendo ponens; or implication elimination; or conditional elimination or affirming the antecedent]
parts: Name this sort of logical problem, where a justification requires a seemingly  unending series of other justifications in order to be valid.
In that paper, Lewis Carroll argued that this type of argument always leads to an infinite regress. This argument is frequently simplified as "if P implies Q and P is true, then Q must be true."
In a book titled for this mathematician and His Rivals, Lewis Carroll argues that 13 different math textbooks are all inferior to, or state the same thing as, this ancient mathematician's Elements.
answers_formatted: modus ponens [or modus ponendo ponens; or implication elimination; or conditional elimination or affirming the antecedent]

bonuses.leadin: Procopius described this general as a man of “deeds of wisdom and manliness” and Agathias described this man as “manly and heroic” despite this man being a known eunuch. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this general who clashed with the Goths during the Byzantine conquest of Italy. His victories included the Battle of Taginae, where he used a crescent formation to decimate the army of Totila.
Narses plotted with this political figure to assassinate John of Cappadocia. According to Procopius, geese ate barley grains off of this person’s naked body.

Narses became this emperor’s favorite general after the Gothic king Vittigis offered to appoint Belisarius “Emperor of the West”, leading to Belisarius’ falling out of favor at this Byzantine emperor’s court.

bonuses.leadin: A table-top device for this technique has a time resolution of roughly 270 picoseconds, and that device uses a source of its namesake antiparticle surrounded by two Kapton foils. For 10 points each:
answers: positron annihilation spectroscopy [or positron annihilation lifetime spectroscopy or PAS or PALS; prompt on partial answers mentioning positrons]
parts: Name this type of spectroscopy that uses its namesake antiparticle to probe defects and voids in solid materials at the sub-nanometer scale.
A common source of positrons for PAS is the unstable 22-isotope of this second-lightest alkali metal. This element shows its bright yellow D-line in a flame test.

Sodium iodide doped with thallium is the most widely-used crystalline material in these particle detectors that emit low energy photons when hit by high-energy particles that are collected and amplified in photomultiplier tubes.
answers_formatted: positron annihilation spectroscopy [or positron annihilation lifetime spectroscopy or PAS or PALS; prompt on partial answers mentioning positrons]

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about musicians known for introducing pedagogical methods. For 10 points each:
answers: Suzuki Shinichi [accept Suzuki method; do not accept or prompt on "Shinichi"]
Guido of Arezzo [prompt on partial answer]
parts: This Japanese violinist’s namesake method begins with variations on "twinkle twinkle little star" before going on to cover the works of Telemann, Dvorak, and Paganini, among others.

This composer's Schulwerk system for musical education makes heavy use of percussion instruments and group chants for children. A choir singing "O Fortuna” opens this composer’s cantata Carmina Burana.

This 11th century monk and pioneering Italian musicologist is credited with proposing the six syllable solmization system, modern staff notation, and a namesake mnemonic system of hand signs that would be heavily incorporated into many modern methods for teaching music.
answers_formatted: Suzuki Shinichi [accept Suzuki method; do not accept or prompt on "Shinichi"]

bonuses.leadin: This character becomes a syphilitic beggar, but explains that syphilis was a necessary byproduct for Europe to get chocolate and cochineal. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this character who espouses "metaphysico-theologo-cosmolonigology" as a parody of the philosopher Gottfried Leibniz. He teaches his students that they live in “the best of all possible worlds.”
Dr. Pangloss appears in this French author’s novel Candide.
A kind-hearted character named James or Jacques, who belongs to this religious sect, falls overboard during the Lisbon earthquake in Candide.

bonuses.leadin: One class of these statements named for Lorentz and Berthelot are used when parametrizing effective-pair potential models. For 10 points each:
answers: combination rules [combining rules; prompt on rules alone]
parts: Name these statements that provide the interaction energy component for two non-bonded atoms. Another set of these statements named for Kong improve upon the Lorentz-Berthelot ones.
Combination rules are relevant to this computer simulation technique, in which Newton’s equations of motions are used to model the physical properties and movements of atoms in complex systems.

Combination rules are particularly useful in simulations of the interaction potential named for this Dutch chemist. This chemist also lends his name to an equation of state that adds terms a and b to the ideal gas law.

bonuses.leadin: These artworks are sometimes covered with a silver gilding calle a riza that only exposes the head and hands of the painting's subjects. For 10 points each:
answers: haloes [or nimbus; or aureole; or glory; or gloriole]
parts: Name these religious artworks used in Catholic and Orthodox Churches, which depict saints or other figures of veneration. Byzantine emperor Leo III initiated some of these artworks' namesake "oclasms."
Icons depicting this figure are sometimes covered by a riza that includes a crown. This figure is known as Theotokos in Eastern Orthodox Churches.
Rizas often contain highly elaborate depictions of these religious art motifs. When displayed on Jesus, these motifs frequently contain the letters omicron, omega, and nu.

bonuses.leadin: Wilhelm Sonderegger cared for this man in the Swiss village of Heiden after he was exiled from Geneva for mismanaging the Credit Genevois. For 10 points each:
answers: International Red Cross [or International Movement of the Red Cross and Red Crescent; accept American Red Cross]
Napoleon III [accept Charles-Louis Napoléon Bonaparte; do NOT prompt on “Napoleon”]
parts: Name this man who was awarded a 1901 prize alongside Frederic Passy. The women of Castiglione feature prominently in his memoir A Memory of Solferino.
Dunant founded this international relief society after witnessing the bloodbath at Solferino. The American analog of this organization was founded by Clara Barton.

The bloodshed at Solferino led this ruler to seek peace through the Armistice of Villafranca. This leader and his uncle were referenced in Marx’s quote “History repeats itself, first as tragedy, then as farce”.
answers_formatted: International Red Cross [or International Movement of the Red Cross or Red Crescent; accept American Red Cross]
Napoleon III [accept Charles-Louis Napoléon Bonaparte; do NOT prompt on “Napoleon”]
acceptable: International Movement of the Red Cross
